children.name: an exact number, amount, time, etc
exact
children.definition: an exact number, amount, or time is completely correct and is no more and no less than it should be:

children.name: the exact amount/number/figure
examples: I don’t know the exact amount, but it was a lot.

children.name: the exact size
examples: First, cut a piece of wood about 1cm x 10cm – the exact size doesn’t matter.

children.name: the exact date
examples: He plans to retire soon, but the exact date is not fixed.

children.name: the exact time/moment
examples: At that exact moment, the phone rang.

children.name: the exact position/location/spot etc
examples: The satellite pictures showed the enemy’s exact location.

children.name: the exact details
children.definition: details that are correct in every way
examples: Nobody knows the exact details of what happened.

children.name: exactly[adverb]
examples: A2 use this to emphasize that a number, amount, or time is no more or less than a particular time or figure:

children.name: ‘Can you tell me the exact time?’ ‘It’s 6.37.’
examples: The exact weight of the baby at birth was 3.2 kg.
You need to give me the exact measurements of the room.
to be exactformalused to after a number to emphasize that what you are saying is exact :
She has worked at the bank for many years, nine to be exact.
It took her about an hour - 58 minutes to be exact.
It’s exactly 5 o'clock.
The bill came to exactly $1000.

children.name: precise
children.definition: precise information is based on clear and exact figures or measurements, especially when it is important that no mistakes are made:
examples: 1precise information, details etc are exact, clear, and correctSYN exact:
precise sales figures
It was difficult to get precise information.
It’s difficult to be precise about the number of deaths caused by smoking.
to be preciseto give precise information or figures
It’s difficult to be precise about the number of deaths caused by smoking.
‘She’s a lot older than you, isn’t she?’ ‘Fifteen years, to be precise .’
2[ only before noun ] used to emphasize that you are referring to an exact thingSYN exact:
At that precise moment, her husband walked in.
The precise cause of the disease is unknown.
the precise location of the ship
the precise nature of their agreement
precisely[adverb] B2
At 3 o'clock precisely, the ceremony began.
She couldn’t describe the car very precisely.

children.name: an exact description, translation, copy, etc
exact
children.definition: an exact copy, model etc of something is like it in every possible way: giống hệt, y chang

children.name: an exact copy/replica
children.definition: something which has been made, that is exactly like another thing
examples: The vessel is an exact replica of a Viking longboat.

children.name: an exact equivalent
children.definition: something that has exactly the same meaning, purpose, value etc as something else
examples: There is no exact equivalent in English for the phrase.

children.name: an exact match
children.definition: something that is exactly the same as something else
examples: The two DNA samples were an exact match.

children.name: sb’s exact words
children.definition: the words someone actually said
examples: Try to remember his exact words – it’s very important.

children.name: the exact wording
children.definition: the words that were used in a letter, speech, etc, with nothing changed
examples: What was the exact wording of the message?

children.name: the exact same thing/way etcinformal
children.definition: exactly the same thing/way etc
examples: If you’d been there, you’d have done the exact same thing.

children.name: an exact replica of a 900-year-old Buddhist shrine
examples: I can’t remember her exact words, but this is the gist of what she said.

children.name: exact likenessuse this about a painting or drawing of someone that looks very much like that person giống y như đúc
examples: It’s not an exact likeness, but it’s recognisable as my father.

children.name: literal
children.definition: 1the  meaning of a word or expression is its basic or original meaning: gốc, nguyên văn, đen
examples: literally[adverb] B2
1according to the most basic or original meaning of a word or expression :
The name of the cheese is Dolcelatte, literally meaning ‘sweet milk’.
2 take sb/sth literallyto believe exactly what someone or something says rather than trying to understand their general meaning :
She takes the Bible literally.
3used to emphasize that something, especially a large number, is actually true :
The Olympic Games were watched by literally billions of people.
Dad was literally blazing with anger.
Vino de tavola' literally means ’table wine'.

children.name: I said I felt like quitting, but I didn’tmeanitliterally
children.definition: I did not mean exactly what I said

children.name: 4spokenused to emphasize a strong expression or word that is not being used in its real or original meaning.
examples: Some people consider this use to be incorrect :

children.name: literal meaning/sense/interpretation etc
examples: A trade war is not a war in the literal sense.
The literal meaning of 'television' is 'seeing from a distance'.
You need to demonstrate to the examiners that you have more than a literal understanding of the text.

children.name: 2 literal translationa translation that translates each word exactly instead of giving the general meaning in a more natural wayOPP free: sát nghĩa, nguyên văn
examples: Her translation is too literal, resulting in heavy, unnatural prose.
It’s rare to use a literal translation of a film title when it is sold abroad.

children.name: word for word
children.definition: if you repeat, copy, or translate sth word for word, you use the exact words that are in it: đúng nguyên văn, theo từng chữ một
examples: ▪ He asked me to repeat word for word the instructions he’d just given me.
▪ The footnote gave a word for word translation of the quotation.

children.name: faithful
children.definition: a faithful copy of sth is as close as possible to the original: “trung thành”
examples: a faithful account of what had happened
afaithful reproductionof the original picture
His model cars are faithful copies of the originals.
This is a faithful interpretation of Shakespeare’s original text.
a faithful reconstruction of an Anglo-Saxon village
faithfully[adverb]
The TV version follows the original novel faithfully.

children.name: strict
children.definition: exact and correct, often in a way that seems unreasonable, ccording to accepted rules or an accepted system:
examples: Dates must be listed in strict chronological order.
Under a strict interpretation of the rules, she would be suspended.

children.name: in the strictest sense of the word
examples: In the strictest sense of the word, all popular fiction is ‘romantic’.
Amy was attractive, although not beautifulin the strictest sense of the word.

children.name: verbatim
children.definition: repeating the exact words that were spoken or written: nguyên văn
examples: ▪ The government released a verbatim transcript of the pilot’s last words.
▪ He lifted passages almost verbatim from an earlier essay he had written.

children.name: exactly
children.definition: use this to give or ask for exact details or information: hoàn toàn đúng
examples: ▪ Glue the pieces together, exactly as shown in the diagram.
▪ It took us exactly two hours to get here.

children.name: exactly who/what/where etc
examples: ▪ The police want to know exactly when you left the building.
▪ The doctors can’t say exactly what’s wrong with my mother.

children.name: exactly the same
examples: ▪ It tastes exactly the same as meat.
who/what/where exactly?
▪ Where exactly are you from?
▪ What exactly did you want to see?

children.name: precisely
children.definition: exactly - use this when it isimportantto describe something very carefully or to get very exact information: chính xác

children.name: precisely what/where/who etc chính xác là cái gì, ai, ở đâu
examples: ▪ We need to know precisely how much this is going to cost.
▪ Can you tell us more precisely what happened?
where/what/who precisely?chính xác là ở đâu, cái gì, ai?
▪ What precisely do you mean by ‘relativity’?

children.name: just
children.definition: especially spoken use this to say exactly how, what, where etc something is: như
examples: ▪ That’s just the right place for the painting, don’t you think?

children.name: just what/how/where etc
examples: ▪ A new handbag! That’s just what I wanted.
▪ Just who does he think he is, coming in here and shouting like that?

children.name: just the same
examples: ▪ He and his brother are just the same -- lazy.

children.name: exactly
children.definition: use this toemphasizethat something is the particular thing that youwantormean: chính xác
examples: ▪ This is exactly the kind of job that computers are good at.
▪ That’s exactly the sort of material I’m looking for.

children.name: exactly what chính xác như
examples: ▪ The earrings are beautiful! They’re exactly what I wanted.
▪ That’s exactly what happened to me!

children.name: precisely
children.definition: exactly - use this toemphasizeexactly what the situation is, exactly what happened, exactly what you meant etc: đúng
examples: ▪ That is precisely the point I was trying to make earlier.
▪ The new legislation won’t solve the problem - it will do precisely the opposite.

children.name: just
children.definition: use this to talk about exactly the thing, person, or place you mean, want etc: chính là
examples: ▪ We want just the same rights as everyone else.
▪ He said he was leaving her and proceeded to do just that!

children.name: just who/what/how etc chính là người, cái gì, thế nào
examples: ▪ I’m not sure just who you mean.
▪ Mallorca? That’s just where we want to go.

children.name: right
children.definition: right in/on/up etc use this when something is in an exact position or place: đúng (chỗ)
examples: ▪ That hit me right in the eye!
▪ I got a mosquito bite right on the end of my nose.
▪ There’s the house, right in front of you.
▪ He sat down right beside her.

children.name: smack
children.definition: in the middle of something/smack in front ofsomething  informal use this to say that something is exactly in a place, especially when this is unpleasant in some way: trực tiếp
examples: ▪ They live smack in the middle of a huge housing estate.
▪ A garbage truck had parked smack in front of our house.

children.name: smack dabAmerican use this to emphasize that you are being exact trực tiếp
examples: ▪ The ball hit me smack dab in the middle of my forehead.

children.name: bang
children.definition: informal bang in/on/up etc use this when something is in an exact point or position, especially if it falls there: đúng
examples: ▪ He landed bang in the middle of the roof, and it collapsed.
▪ The eraser hit him bang on the top of his head.

children.name: right/slap bang đúng vào bên phải, tát đúng vào
examples: ▪ The arrow hit the target right bang in the middle.
▪ They’ve put an ornamental fountain slap bang in the middle of the roundabout.

children.name: doing sth in exactly the right way
exactly
children.definition: use this to talk about doing something in exactly the right way: chính xác
examples: ▪ Assemble the table exactly as shown in the diagram on the left.
▪ I don’t exactly know how to dry herbs, could you show me?
▪ You must do exactly as I say.

children.name: strictly
children.definition: done exactly according to a set of rules or instructions: nghiêm túc
examples: ▪ The work is strictly on a volunteer basis.
▪ The immigration laws have been strictly implemented.
▪ Martha and Joan kept strictly to their part of the house.

children.name: religiously
children.definition: if you do something religiously, you do it in exactly the way that you are supposed to do it: y như thế
examples: ▪ He counted his money up religiously every night.
▪ Julia has been sticking religiously to her diet.

children.name: inaccuracy
children.definition: 1 a statement that is not completely correct:
examples: Jansen’s review contained several inaccuracies.
The film is full of historical inaccuracies.

children.name: fine
children.definition: adjectiveEXACT

children.name: accuracy
children.definition: the quality of being correct or trueOPP inaccuracy
examples: We double checked the figures to ensure their accuracy.
accuracy of
worries about the accuracy of government statistic

children.name: technically
children.definition: adverb
examples: according to an exact understanding of rules, facts, etc.
_Technically, the country's economic problems are over but recovery will be slow.

children.name: _young people who are technically still children
strictly speaking
children.definition: being completely accurate
examples: _Strictly speaking, Great Britain consists of Scotland,WalesandEngland, and theUnited Kingdomconsists ofGreat BritainandNorthern Ireland.
